title: I feel like Riot's skin team isn't on the same page as champion design.
body:
It's never been a secret that Officer Caitlyn is supposed to be a "stripper-dressed-as-a-cop" rather than an actual police officer. It's acceptable because the skin was made when Riot was still in their "teenage" years, and Caitlyn is a pretty sexualized character anyways.

http://img3.wikia.nocookie.net/__cb20111005043436/leagueoflegends/images/2/23/Caitlyn_OfficerSkin.jpg

Then the champion designers goes and creates Vi: A tomboy that isn't afraid to show that she is female (ex. pink hair), but is definitely not eyecandy. 

http://img2.wikia.nocookie.net/__cb20121212052715/leagueoflegends/images/a/a0/Vi_OriginalSkin.jpg

Then the skin team gives *her* a skin of the same theme. I'm personally not a fan of it because it doesn't fit the character, but I can look the other way considering it's a "matching skin" (since she and Caitlyn are partners) and it was released as kind of a halloween costume. The also only made her sexualized because it was part of the skin theme.

http://img3.wikia.nocookie.net/__cb20141116061957/leagueoflegends/images/2/20/Vi_OfficerSkin.jpg

And then they make these in the same skin serie:

http://3.bp.blogspot.com/-Y0IaO5dv_KY/VGrjohKzaVI/AAAAAAAAdik/wo1Y4LZC5a4/s1600/Trundle_Splash_4.jpg

Oh look, now there's a **troll** and a **bear** who are easier to take seriously than the two people who are **actual police officers lore-wise.** 

Other skin-themes have the same problem. The medical skins for the ninjas for example (although those skins are older, but still).

I feel like while the rest of Riot's design team are growing up, the skin team is still locked up inside it's mom's basement.

I'm probably stepping in a den of lions, but whenever I stumble upon threads like this a question comes to my mind: why any display of sexiness from a female figure makes people scream about the objectification of women and of strippers (as if they were *evil incarnated* and didn't have any human dimension), while an analogous display from a male character doesn't raise any objection nor commotion?
The male body too is objectified, just look at the latest movie trends when it comes to muscles, the bar has been raised a whole lot and shirtless scenes are really common.
I'd say there are actually two male body types being enforced to us as society's standard: the skinny one and the good-looking-muscled one (as opposed to the strongman-muscled one, which is very different). Why isn't anyone discussing it? Why it's always a matter of how much skin female characters show? Why can guys be represented as muscled and shirtless but female wearing miniskirts are deemed "strippers"? Why should the profession of stripper be used as a denigrative term? Can't strippers be human being like all the rest and have a human dimension which goes beyond the act of stripping they perform at work?
Besides, scantily clad women equating to "strippers" or to sexualized objects or to "whores" is pretty primitive and goes back to the chauvinist conception that women who dress like that are no good. Can't a woman choose how much of her body show, in which manner and what it does mean for her? Are miniskirts and cleavage showing dresses only a sign of low moral or the will to play the sexual object part? Can't a dignified and proud woman just dress however she pleases and maybe feel good about it, because she thinks she really looks beautiful that way, without having to think about people pointing her as an object?

I'm a man and if I were a handsome muscled one I would have no problem showing it (not going shirtless though, we're not in a movie and scantily clad women don't do that either), but would that mean I would be a male stripper? Would that mean that I'm bending myself to the image of men the media feed us and just being an eye-candy for women?

How a person dresses and presents her-/him-self has obviously a lot of repercussions in the interactions with those surrounding said person, but it should be kept in mind that looks are not a sign of moral fibre and people should be free to express themselves with their looks as a mean of self-discovery and self-satisfaction too.

Well, [firstly](http://septembriseur.tumblr.com/post/94553353969/wow-ok-i-had-kind-of-conceptualized-that-joss), what women find attractive in men is not what men think women find attractive in men. Hypermuscled men are a male power fantasy, while sexeh strippah ladiez are a male sexual fantasy. League doesn't really have anything I'd class as a pure female power fantasy, since nearly all female champions are portrayed as being within the realm of conventionally attractive in face and body type.

Citing the link you provided, it is true that Hugh Jackman bulging-veined is a sight liked by men, while a women's magazine had him rather donning a sweater and smiling, but that doesn't mean that no woman likes muscles.
I think that the skinny, "feminine" type of guy a la Loki is actually more popular nowadays (especially in eastern countries), but this doesn't invalidate the fact that male characters in League have primarily two body types, muscled and skinny, and that male bodies are being objectified in advertisement just as female ones. We could argue all day whether advertisers are doing it right by understanding what women want or are just enforcing their stereotypes on society, but anyway we end at the same point: if women actually like what advertisers do, they'll keep doing it and there will be a positive feedback which will amplify the effect, if they don't and advertisers keep enforcing stereotypes there's the serious possibility for those stereotypes to be forced to become true and we're back to case A.
I read an article some time ago explaining of a certain beer brand in the USA which through marketing imposed the view that beer should be drunk ice cold and that their beer was better because served that way. Their beer wasn't superior in taste, but serving it ice cold masks the taste and people were led into thinking ice cold is the way to drink beer and that other beers were worse because they drank them at a superior temperature, which didn't mask the taste. It doesn't matter that the other brand probably tastes worse at the same temperature, because they're the ones serving it ice-cold. You can find it [here](http://www.polygon.com/features/2013/12/2/5143856/no-girls-allowed), just ctrl+f for the beer part. I'd suggest reading it all though, it's about marketing and gender in gaming.

I think that champions being somewhat good-looking has deeper roots and kind of descends from the ancient concept of *καλὸς καὶ ἀγαθός* (good and handsome; second time I get to cite it on the boards xD) and classical heroes being beautiful too. There's a whole lot of cultural bias towards deformations, deviations from the norm and ugly aspects which is not a matter of sexism and indeed applies to males too.
For instance, orcs are your typical example of moral evil transpiring from ugly appearance. Their ugliness is a depiction of their immorality and ferality in most standard settings. Of course narrative has progressed a lot since the times when this was a strict norm and we have things such as Warcraft, where Orcs get a much more modern depiction and aren't necessarily the bad guys.
I'd say that over the course of time we've just got to a point where main characters are generally good looking, save for those characters who have as a feature the fact of being an exception. That's because they're meant to be showcased and this is the easiest way to strike the audience and have them focus on those characters. But this isn't a matter of sexism, it applies to both sexes and to products catered for females as well.

A few things:

First of all, they're not part of the same skin line. There is "Officer Caitlyn" and "Officer Vi" on one hand (that because they share names, they share the theme of "skimpy, over-sexualized"), and then there is "Captain Volibear" and "Constable Trundle", (which share a splash art, so those two are free to follow a different theme).

Also, I have to ask you to look at that splash art again. Do Volibear and Trundle really look like *believable* police officers? They're huge, muscley, and are non-chalantly walking away from an explosion. These two skins are as much a non-sensical parody as the Officer skins are.
